trans-unit.source: Integrate Azure Active Directory single sign-on with SaaS apps | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Integrate Azure Active Directory single sign-on with SaaS apps | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Enable single sign-on authentication and user provisioning centralized access management of SaaS apps in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Enable single sign-on authentication and user provisioning centralized access management of SaaS apps in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: An overview of how to integrate Azure Active Directory to SaaS apps.
trans-unit.target: An overview of how to integrate Azure Active Directory to SaaS apps.

trans-unit.source: Integrate Azure Active Directory single sign-on with SaaS apps
trans-unit.target: Integrate Azure Active Directory single sign-on with SaaS apps

trans-unit.source: To get started setting up single sign-on for an app that you’re bringing into your organization, you will be using an existing directory in Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
trans-unit.target: To get started setting up single sign-on for an app that you’re bringing into your organization, you will be using an existing directory in Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).

trans-unit.source: You can use an Azure AD directory that you obtain through Microsoft Azure, Office 365, or Windows Intune.
trans-unit.target: You can use an Azure AD directory that you obtain through Microsoft Azure, Office 365, or Windows Intune.

trans-unit.source: If you have two or more of these, see [Administer your Azure AD directory](active-directory-administer.md) to determine which one to use.
trans-unit.target: If you have two or more of these, see [Administer your Azure AD directory](active-directory-administer.md) to determine which one to use.

trans-unit.source: Authentication
trans-unit.target: Authentication

trans-unit.source: For applications that support the SAML 2.0, WS-Federation, or OpenID Connect protocols, Azure Active Directory uses signing certificates to establish trust relationships.
trans-unit.target: For applications that support the SAML 2.0, WS-Federation, or OpenID Connect protocols, Azure Active Directory uses signing certificates to establish trust relationships.

trans-unit.source: For more information about this, see [Managing certificates for federated single sign-on](active-directory-sso-certs.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about this, see [Managing certificates for federated single sign-on](active-directory-sso-certs.md).

trans-unit.source: For applications that support only HTML forms-based sign-in, Azure Active Directory uses ‘password vaulting’ to establish trust relationships.
trans-unit.target: For applications that support only HTML forms-based sign-in, Azure Active Directory uses ‘password vaulting’ to establish trust relationships.

trans-unit.source: This enables the users in your organization to be automatically signed in to a SaaS application by Azure AD using the user account information from the SaaS application.
trans-unit.target: This enables the users in your organization to be automatically signed in to a SaaS application by Azure AD using the user account information from the SaaS application.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD collects and securely stores the user account information and the related password.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD collects and securely stores the user account information and the related password.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Password-based single sign-on](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md\#password-based-single-sign-on).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Password-based single sign-on](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md\#password-based-single-sign-on).

trans-unit.source: Authorization
trans-unit.target: Authorization

trans-unit.source: A provisioned account enables a user to be authorized to use an application after they have authenticated through single sign-on.
trans-unit.target: A provisioned account enables a user to be authorized to use an application after they have authenticated through single sign-on.

trans-unit.source: User provisioning can be done manually, or in some cases you can add and remove user information from the SaaS app based on changes made in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: User provisioning can be done manually, or in some cases you can add and remove user information from the SaaS app based on changes made in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using existing Azure AD connectors for automated provisioning, see [Automated user provisioning and de-provisioning for SaaS applications](active-directory-saas-app-provisioning.md)
trans-unit.target: For more information on using existing Azure AD connectors for automated provisioning, see [Automated user provisioning and de-provisioning for SaaS applications](active-directory-saas-app-provisioning.md)

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, you can manually add user information to an app, or use other provisioning solutions that are available in the marketplace.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, you can manually add user information to an app, or use other provisioning solutions that are available in the marketplace.

trans-unit.source: Access
trans-unit.target: Access

trans-unit.source: Azure AD provides several customizable ways to deploy applications to end users in your organization.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD provides several customizable ways to deploy applications to end users in your organization.

trans-unit.source: You are not locked into any particular deployment or access solution.
trans-unit.target: You are not locked into any particular deployment or access solution.

trans-unit.source: You can use [the solution that best suits your needs](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md#deploying-azure-ad-integrated-applications-to-users).
trans-unit.target: You can use [the solution that best suits your needs](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md#deploying-azure-ad-integrated-applications-to-users).

trans-unit.source: Additional considerations for applications already in use
trans-unit.target: Additional considerations for applications already in use

trans-unit.source: Setting up single sign on for an application that your organization already uses is a different process from the process of creating new accounts for a new application.
trans-unit.target: Setting up single sign on for an application that your organization already uses is a different process from the process of creating new accounts for a new application.

trans-unit.source: There are a couple of preliminary steps including: mapping user identities in the application to Azure AD identities, and understanding how users will experience logging in to an application after it is integrated.
trans-unit.target: There are a couple of preliminary steps including: mapping user identities in the application to Azure AD identities, and understanding how users will experience logging in to an application after it is integrated.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To set up SSO for an existing application, you need to have global administrator rights in both Azure AD and the SaaS application.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To set up SSO for an existing application, you need to have global administrator rights in both Azure AD and the SaaS application.

trans-unit.source: Mapping user accounts
trans-unit.target: Mapping user accounts

trans-unit.source: A user's identity typically has a unique identifier that could be an email address, or universal personal name (UPN).
trans-unit.target: A user's identity typically has a unique identifier that could be an email address, or universal personal name (UPN).

trans-unit.source: You will need to link (map) each user's application identity to their respective Azure AD identity.
trans-unit.target: You will need to link (map) each user's application identity to their respective Azure AD identity.

trans-unit.source: There are a couple of ways to accomplish this depending on how the requirement of your application authentication.
trans-unit.target: There are a couple of ways to accomplish this depending on how the requirement of your application authentication.

trans-unit.source: For more information about mapping application identities with Azure AD identities, see [Customizing claims issued in the SAML token](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/31257.azure-active-directory-customizing-claims-issued-in-the-saml-token-for-pre-integrated-apps.aspx) and [Customizing attribute mappings for provisioning](active-directory-saas-customizing-attribute-mappings.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about mapping application identities with Azure AD identities, see [Customizing claims issued in the SAML token](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/31257.azure-active-directory-customizing-claims-issued-in-the-saml-token-for-pre-integrated-apps.aspx) and [Customizing attribute mappings for provisioning](active-directory-saas-customizing-attribute-mappings.md).

trans-unit.source: Understanding the user's log in experience
trans-unit.target: Understanding the user's log in experience

trans-unit.source: When you integrate SSO for an application that’s already in use, it’s important to realize that the user experience will be affected.
trans-unit.target: When you integrate SSO for an application that’s already in use, it’s important to realize that the user experience will be affected.

trans-unit.source: For all applications, users will start using their Azure AD credentials to sign in.
trans-unit.target: For all applications, users will start using their Azure AD credentials to sign in.

trans-unit.source: It could also be that they must use a different portal to access the applications.
trans-unit.target: It could also be that they must use a different portal to access the applications.

trans-unit.source: SSO for some applications can be done on the application's sign in interface, but for other applications, the user will have to go through a central portal such as ([My Apps](http://myapps.microsoft.com) or [Office365](http://portal.office.com/myapps)) to sign in.
trans-unit.target: SSO for some applications can be done on the application's sign in interface, but for other applications, the user will have to go through a central portal such as ([My Apps](http://myapps.microsoft.com) or [Office365](http://portal.office.com/myapps)) to sign in.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about the different types of SSO and their user experiences in [What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md).
trans-unit.target: Learn more about the different types of SSO and their user experiences in [What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md).

trans-unit.source: Another valuable resource is *Suppressing user consent* in the [Guiding developers](active-directory-applications-guiding-developers-for-lob-applications.md) article.
trans-unit.target: Another valuable resource is *Suppressing user consent* in the [Guiding developers](active-directory-applications-guiding-developers-for-lob-applications.md) article.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For SaaS apps that you find in the App Gallery, Azure AD provides a number of [tutorials on how to integrate SaaS apps](active-directory-saas-tutorial-list.md).
trans-unit.target: For SaaS apps that you find in the App Gallery, Azure AD provides a number of [tutorials on how to integrate SaaS apps](active-directory-saas-tutorial-list.md).

trans-unit.source: If app is not in App Gallery, you can [add it to the Azure AD App Gallery as a custom application](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/17/bring-your-own-app-with-azure-ad-self-service-saml-configuration-gt-now-in-preview.aspx).
trans-unit.target: If app is not in App Gallery, you can [add it to the Azure AD App Gallery as a custom application](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/17/bring-your-own-app-with-azure-ad-self-service-saml-configuration-gt-now-in-preview.aspx).

trans-unit.source: There is much more detail on all of these issues in the Azure.com library,
trans-unit.target: There is much more detail on all of these issues in the Azure.com library,

trans-unit.source: beginning with [What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory.](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md).
trans-unit.target: beginning with [What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory.](active-directory-appssoaccess-whatis.md).
